Experimental Objectives Due to the difficulty in obtaining real strain data from fatigue-sensitive locations on floating offshore platforms, this study uses measured strain data from typical fatigue-sensitive components to validate the fatigue life prediction algorithm; Considering the corrosion susceptibility of metal structures in marine environments, modified S-N curves are used in conjunction with standards to calculate fatigue factors; Mooring Chain Corrosion Degradation Mechanism Modified S-N curve expressions fitted from the dataset:
$$ \log N = 12.249 - 0.0507 \cdot \lambda_m - 0.106 \cdot c - 3.0 \cdot \log S $$$$ \log N = 12.143 - 0.0507 \cdot \lambda_m - 0.673 \cdot \log c - 3.0 \cdot \log S $$S-N curve expressions proposed according to design specifications:
$$ \log N = 11.904 - 0.0507 \cdot \lambda_m - 0.106 \cdot c - 3.0 \cdot \log S $$$$ \log N = 11.797 - 0.0507 \cdot \lambda_m - 0.673 \cdot \log c - 3.0 \cdot \log S $$ $\lambda_m$ is the mean load ratio expressed as a percentage of the Minimum Breaking Load (MBL) c is the defined corrosion grade, ranging from 1 (new chain) to 7 (severe corrosion) Data Processing Workflow Collect daily strain data and convert it to stress spectrum through rainflow counting method, combining material elastic modulus; Calculate fatigue damage factors based on S-N curves for specific corrosion grades: Mark fatigue damage factors as NaN for periods with missing sensor data; Remove outliers using 3σ criterion to ensure data quality; Construct annual fatigue damage factor series (365×1 vector) as input for the BDLM (Bayesian Dynamic Linear Model) framework; Through BDLM model predict future distribution characteristics of fatigue damage factors to support structural health monitoring and maintenance decisions. BDLM Algorithm Principles Model Definition BDLM consists of two equations:
$$ \text{Observation equation: }y_t = F_t^\top \theta_t + v_t, \quad v_t \sim \mathcal{N}(0, V_t) $$$$ \text{State equation: }\theta_t = G_t\theta_{t-1} + w_t, \quad w_t \sim \mathcal{N}(0, W_t) $$ $y_t \in \mathbb{R} \text{ is the observation at time } t$
$\theta_t \in \mathbb{R}^n \text{ is the hidden state vector}$
$F_t \in \mathbb{R}^n \text{ is the observation design matrix}$
$G_t \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n} \text{ is the state transition matrix}$
$v_t \text{ and } w_t \text{ are independent Gaussian noise with covariances } V_t \text{ and } W_t$
Bayesian Recursive Framework BDLM’s core is combining prior distribution with likelihood through Bayes’ theorem to obtain posterior distribution. The recursion involves two steps:
Prediction Step: Use state equation to derive prior of $θ_t$ from posterior of $θ_{t−1}$; Update Step: Combine observation $y_t$ to update posterior of $θ_t$; Step 1: Prediction (Prior Distribution)
Assume posterior distribution at time $t-1$ is:
$$ \theta_{t-1} \mid y_{1:t-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(m_{t-1}, C_{t-1}) $$Predict prior distribution at time $t$ through state equation:
$$ \theta_t \mid y_{1:t-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(a_t, R_t) \\ a_t = G_t m_{t-1}, R_t = G_t C_{t-1} G_t^\top + W_t $$ Linear transformation of state equation: $\theta_t = G_t\theta_{t-1} + w_t$; Gaussian distribution property under linear transformation: if $\theta_t \sim \mathcal{N}(m_{t-1}, C_{t-1})$, then $G_t\theta_{t-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(G_t m_{t-1}, G_t C_{t-1} G_t)$; Add noise to derive final result; Step 2: Update (Posterior Distribution)
Likelihood from observation equation:
$$ y_t \mid \theta_t \sim \mathcal{N}(F_t^\top \theta_t, V_t) $$Combine with prior $\theta_t \mid y_{1:t-1} \sim \mathcal{N}(a_t, R_t)$, use Bayes’ theorem to calculate posterior
$$ p(\theta_t | y_{1:t}) \propto p(y_t | \theta_t)p(\theta_t | y_{1:t-1}) $$Update mean and covariance using Gaussian conditional distribution formula:
$$ \theta_t \mid y_{1:t} \sim \mathcal{N}(m_t, C_t) \\ m_t = a_t + R_t F_t Q_t^{-1} (y_t - F_t^\top a_t)， C_t = R_t - R_t F_t Q_t^{-1} F_t^\top R_t \ $$Case Study State vector comprises five key components, $X=[X^{LL},X^P,X^{AR}]$:
Base level term $X^{LL}$
Seasonal variation term (period: 365/4 days) $X^{P1}$
Dual periodic terms (period: 7 days, two sets) $ X^{P2},X^{P3}$
First-order autoregressive term (for residuals) $X^{AR}$
Observation design matrix: defines how observations are extracted from states;
If only observing first component (level term) of state vector, then $F_t=[1,0,…,0]^T$ State transition matrix: describes how states evolve over time;
Base level term
$$ \mathbf{A}^{LT} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \end{bmatrix} $$ Periodic term (Fourier form)
$$ \mathbf{A}^P = \begin{bmatrix} \cos\omega & \sin\omega \\ -\sin\omega & \cos\omega \end{bmatrix} $$ Results Demonstration Calculate stress spectrum for each month, below shows stress spectrum distribution for April 2006:

Prediction Results Analysis:
Model predictions (blue solid line) show high agreement with measured values;
Predictions include confidence intervals (light blue region);
Confidence intervals widen in data-missing periods, reflecting increased uncertainty;
Model demonstrates excellent fitting performance in periods with complete data;
Use model trained on 2006 data to predict fatigue damage factors for 2007; References [1] J. Heng, Y. Dong, L. Lai, Z. Zhou, and D. M. Frangopol, “Digital twins-boosted intelligent maintenance of ageing bridge hangers exposed to coupled corrosion–fatigue deterioration,” Automation in Construction, vol. 167, p. 105697, Nov. 2024, doi: 10.1016/j.autcon.2024.105697.
